definitions: demanding task requiring effort and skill to overcome
formal objection or dispute to something claimed or asserted
act of questioning authority, beliefs, or accepted ideas
examples: Learning a new language presents a significant challenge for adults
The mountain climb was the greatest challenge she ever faced
The defense lawyer issued a challenge to the witness testimony
Several challenges were filed against the election results
Her challenge to traditional teaching methods sparked heated debate
Young people often challenge societal norms and expectations

definitions: person who questions or disputes something, especially authority or ideas
competitor who attempts to defeat the current champion or holder
examples: The young challenger questioned every assumption in the theory
She emerged as the main challenger to his leadership
The heavyweight challenger trained intensively for the title fight
Several challengers entered the race against the incumbent

definitions: room used for specific purpose, especially formal or private
hall where legislative or judicial body meets and deliberates
enclosed space or cavity within structure, organ, or machine
examples: The judge retired to his private chambers for deliberation
The torture chamber contained medieval instruments of pain
The upper chamber voted against the proposed legislation
Members of the chamber debated the issue for hours
The heart has four chambers that pump blood efficiently
The combustion chamber must withstand extreme temperatures and pressure

definitions: lizard capable of changing skin color to match surroundings
person who changes behavior or opinions to suit different situations
examples: The chameleon turned green when placed on the leafy branch
Madagascar hosts numerous endemic chameleon species found nowhere else
He's a political chameleon who shifts positions with public opinion
She was a social chameleon, fitting seamlessly into any group

definitions: informal term for champion or winner in competition
action of biting or chewing something repeatedly and noisily
examples: The boxing champ defended his title successfully last night
She's the reigning champ in the regional chess tournament
The horse was champing at the bit impatiently
He champed on his cigar while reading the newspaper

definitions: sparkling white wine produced in Champagne region of France
pale yellowish or golden color resembling the wine
examples: They celebrated with expensive champagne from a vintage year
The champagne bubbles tickled her nose as she sipped
She wore a champagne colored dress to the wedding
The car came in champagne metallic paint finish

definitions: person or team that wins first place in competition
person who fights for or defends a cause or person
examples: The tennis champion won her fifth consecutive grand slam
They crowned a new world champion after the final match
She became a champion for women's rights in education
The senator championed environmental protection throughout his career

definitions: contest or series of contests to determine the winner
position or period of being champion in a sport
examples: The championship match drew millions of viewers worldwide
Teams compete annually for the national championship trophy
During his championship, he defended the title twelve times
Her championship lasted three years before she retired

definitions: likelihood or possibility that something will happen
favorable opportunity or occasion to do something
unpredictable element or occurrence without apparent cause
examples: There's a good chance of rain tomorrow afternoon
What are the chances of winning the lottery jackpot
This job offers a chance to travel internationally
She never got another chance to apologize
They met by pure chance at the airport
It was chance that brought them together again

definitions: senior government minister, especially in Germany or Austria
ceremonial or executive head of a university
examples: The German Chancellor announced new economic policies yesterday
The Chancellor of the Exchequer presented the annual budget
The university chancellor presided over the graduation ceremony
She was appointed chancellor after decades of academic service

definitions: position or office held by a chancellor
period during which someone serves as chancellor
examples: She assumed the chancellorship after winning the election decisively
The chancellorship carries significant executive powers and responsibilities
His chancellorship lasted eight years and transformed the nation
During her chancellorship, the university doubled its endowment

definitions: ornamental hanging light fixture with multiple branches for bulbs or candles
examples: The crystal chandelier sparkled magnificently in the ballroom
They carefully cleaned each piece of the antique chandelier

definitions: act or instance of making or becoming different
coins of low denomination or money returned from payment
fresh set of clothes or different items to replace others
examples: Climate change poses serious threats to coastal communities
The company underwent major changes in management structure
Do you have change for a twenty dollar bill
She dropped her loose change into the charity box
Pack a change of clothes for after the game
The baby needs a change of diapers immediately

definitions: process of changing from one system, method, or situation to another
examples: The changeover to digital broadcasting took several years
Production stopped during the changeover to new equipment

definitions: device that automatically changes something, especially records or CDs
person who makes changes or exchanges things
examples: The CD changer holds six discs for continuous play
Install a money changer near the vending machines
He worked as a money changer at the border
She's a game changer in the tech industry

definitions: natural or artificial waterway for water to flow through
television or radio station broadcasting on specific frequency
route or means through which information or resources flow
examples: Ships navigate carefully through the narrow channel
The English Channel separates Britain from continental Europe
She changed the channel to watch the evening news
The sports channel broadcasts games twenty-four hours daily
Communication channels between departments need significant improvement
They distributed products through multiple retail channels

definitions: song with repetitive rhythm, especially in religious services
words or slogan shouted repeatedly by crowd or group
examples: The monks performed their morning chant at sunrise
Gregorian chants echoed through the ancient cathedral
Protesters raised their voices in unified chant
The crowd's chant grew louder as the team scored

definitions: person who sings chants, especially in religious contexts
pipe with finger holes on bagpipes producing the melody
examples: The lead chanter guided the congregation through the hymns
Buddhist chanters filled the temple with sacred sounds
He carefully cleaned the chanter of his Scottish bagpipes
The chanter produces the melody while drones provide harmony

definitions: practice or action of singing or reciting with repetitive rhythm
examples: The chanting continued throughout the meditation session
Religious chanting helps practitioners focus their minds

definitions: informal term for man or boy, especially British usage
crack or sore in skin caused by cold or dryness
examples: The old chap shared fascinating stories from his travels
He's a decent chap who always helps his neighbors
Winter weather caused painful chaps on her hands
Use moisturizer to prevent chapped lips in cold weather

definitions: small building or room used for Christian worship
part of larger building designated for religious services
examples: The wedding took place in a quaint countryside chapel
Students gathered for prayers in the school chapel
The hospital chapel provides comfort to patients and families
They built a private chapel within the castle walls

definitions: adult who accompanies and supervises young people at social events
examples: Parent volunteers served as chaperones for the school dance
The chaperone ensured proper behavior during the field trip

definitions: member of clergy attached to institution, military unit, or private chapel
examples: The hospital chaplain offered spiritual support to patients
Military chaplains serve soldiers regardless of their faith

definitions: position or department of chaplain within an institution
examples: The university chaplaincy offers counseling to students of all faiths
She accepted a chaplaincy position at the regional hospital

definitions: main division of a book, typically numbered or titled
local branch of a society, fraternity, or other organization
distinct period or sequence of events in life or history
examples: The most exciting events happen in chapter twelve
Each chapter explores a different aspect of the theory
The local chapter meets monthly at the community center
She joined the honor society chapter at her university
This promotion marks a new chapter in her career
The scandal was a dark chapter in the company's history

definitions: partially burned or blackened material from fire
person employed to clean houses or offices, British usage
small trout-like fish living in cold waters
examples: The char from the fireplace needed regular cleaning
Wood char can be used as natural fertilizer
The char arrives twice weekly to clean the offices
She worked as a char to support her family
Arctic char thrive in the coldest mountain lakes
The restaurant served grilled char with lemon butter

definitions: mental and moral qualities distinctive to an individual
person in novel, play, or movie portrayed by actor
printed or written letter, symbol, or distinctive mark
examples: Her strong character helped her overcome many obstacles
The job requires someone of impeccable character and integrity
The main character faces numerous challenges throughout the story
He played the character of a detective brilliantly
Chinese characters represent words rather than individual sounds
The password must contain at least one special character

definitions: process of describing distinctive nature or features of someone or something
examples: The author's characterisation of the villain was remarkably nuanced
Her characterisation of the situation proved entirely accurate

definitions: typical feature or quality that distinguishes someone or something
examples: Patience is a characteristic essential for teaching young children
The building displays characteristics typical of Victorian architecture

definitions: process of describing distinctive nature or features of someone or something
examples: The playwright's characterization brings each personality vividly to life
Scientific characterization of the compound took several months

definitions: absurd pretense intended to create pleasant or respectable appearance
game where players guess word or phrase from acted clues
examples: Their marriage had become a charade maintained for appearances
The trial was a charade with the verdict predetermined
We played charades at the party last night
She's excellent at acting out difficult charades

definitions: black carbon residue from partially burned wood used for fuel or drawing
dark gray color resembling the carbon material
examples: Artists use charcoal for sketching and drawing portraits
We grilled steaks over hot charcoal for dinner
He wore a charcoal suit to the business meeting
The walls were painted in charcoal gray tones

definitions: leafy green vegetable with colorful stalks related to beets
examples: Swiss chard grows abundantly in the summer garden
She sautéed rainbow chard with garlic and olive oil

definitions: price asked for goods or services provided
quantity of electrical energy stored in or carried by something
formal accusation of crime made against someone
rushing attack or assault, especially in battle
examples: The charge for delivery is ten dollars extra
There's no charge for children under five years old
The battery holds enough charge for eight hours use
Static charge built up in the dry winter air
He faces charges of fraud and money laundering
The prosecutor filed charges against three suspects
The cavalry charge broke through enemy lines decisively
The bull lowered its head and prepared to charge

definitions: device for charging batteries or electronic devices with electricity
strong horse historically used in battle or by cavalry
examples: Don't forget to pack your phone charger for the trip
The laptop charger stopped working after two years
Knights rode powerful chargers into medieval battles
The general's charger was a magnificent black stallion

definitions: two-wheeled vehicle drawn by horses used in ancient warfare and racing
examples: Roman chariots raced around the Circus Maximus track
The pharaoh rode a golden chariot into battle

definitions: person who drives a chariot, especially in ancient races or battles
examples: The skilled charioteer won numerous races at the colosseum
Egyptian charioteers were elite warriors in ancient armies

definitions: compelling attractiveness or charm that inspires devotion in others
examples: The politician's natural charisma won over skeptical voters
She possessed the charisma needed to lead the organization

definitions: organization providing help and raising money for those in need
voluntary giving of help, typically money, to those in need
kindness and tolerance in judging others
examples: The charity provides meals for homeless families every day
She volunteers at a local children's charity
All proceeds from the event go to charity
Their charity helped rebuild the storm-damaged school
Show some charity when judging others' mistakes
Christian charity teaches forgiveness and compassion

definitions: person falsely claiming to have special knowledge or skill; a fraud
examples: The supposed healer was exposed as a charlatan
Many charlatans prey on desperate patients seeking miracle cures

definitions: dessert made of fruit, typically in a bread or sponge cake mold
examples: The apple charlotte was served warm with vanilla custard
She prepared a traditional charlotte russe for dessert

definitions: quality of being attractive, pleasing, or delightful to others
small ornament worn on bracelet or chain for decoration
object, act, or words believed to have magical power
examples: Her natural charm made everyone feel comfortable and welcome
The old town retained its rustic charm despite modernization
She collected silver charms from every country she visited
The bracelet jangled with dozens of tiny charms
The witch cast a charm to protect the village
He wore a lucky charm during every game

definitions: person with an attractive, engaging personality who easily wins others over
person who appears to control snakes through music or movement
examples: He's quite the charmer at social gatherings
The smooth-talking charmer convinced her to invest
The snake charmer performed with cobras in the marketplace
Traditional snake charmers use flutes to mesmerize serpents

definitions: sheet of information in form of table, graph, or diagram
map used for navigation, especially at sea or in air
weekly listing of currently most popular music recordings
examples: The chart shows sales increasing steadily over five years
Doctors consulted the patient's temperature chart
The captain studied the nautical chart before setting sail
Pilots rely on aeronautical charts for flight planning
Their new single topped the charts for six weeks
The album debuted at number one on the charts

definitions: written grant of rights or privileges from sovereign or authority
hiring of aircraft, ship, or vehicle for private use
examples: The university operates under a royal charter from 1836
The charter guarantees certain fundamental rights to citizens
They arranged a charter flight for the sports team
The fishing charter includes all equipment and bait

definitions: French liqueur made by Carthusian monks from herbs
vivid yellow-green color resembling the liqueur
examples: The monks still produce chartreuse using the secret recipe
He ordered a glass of green chartreuse after dinner
She painted the accent wall in bright chartreuse
The designer chose chartreuse fabric for the cushions

definitions: act of pursuing someone or something to catch or catch up
groove or furrow cut for decorative purposes or to receive an object
examples: The police chase lasted over an hour through city streets
The cat gave chase when the mouse ran
The jeweler cut a delicate chase in the silver
Electricians ran wires through the chase in the wall

definitions: person or thing that pursues or hunts someone or something
drink taken after another of different kind, especially after liquor
examples: The storm chaser tracked tornadoes across three states
Ambulance chasers give lawyers a bad reputation
He ordered a beer chaser after the whiskey shot
Lemon juice makes a good chaser for tequila

definitions: deep fissure in earth's surface or rock formation
profound difference between people, viewpoints, or situations
examples: A deep chasm opened in the earth after the earthquake
They carefully crossed the mountain chasm using ropes
The chasm between rich and poor continues to widen
There's a growing chasm between the two political parties

definitions: base frame of vehicle, including wheels and machinery, supporting the body
examples: The car's chassis was damaged beyond repair in the accident
Engineers reinforced the chassis to improve vehicle stability
